summary:
We need to produce JSON with keys: summary, business_intent, keywords (list). Must not list method names verbatim. Focus on class responsibility and state/behavior. Provide English description.

Class LazyStream: wrapper that allows get and "unget" bytes from a stream. It takes a producer iterator yielding bytestrings, supports iteration, reading, and keeping a look-back variable to unget bytes.

So summary: A lazy stream wrapper that reads bytes from an underlying iterator on demand, provides standard stream interface (iteration, read, tell) and allows pushing back bytes (unget) for later re-reading.

Business intent: To enable parsers or consumers to read from a byte source lazily while being able to backtrack a few bytes without reloading the whole source, useful for incremental parsing, protocol handling, etc.

Keywords: lazy, stream, iterator, bytes, unget, backtrack, read, tell, close, buffering, look-back.

Make sure not to list method names verbatim. Avoid "read", "unget"? The instruction says "Do NOT list method names verbatim." So we cannot include method names like "read", "unget", "close", "parts", "__iter__", etc. So we must avoid those words exactly as method names. However we can use synonyms like "retrieve data", "push back bytes". But "read" is a common word; but they said "method names verbatim". The method name "read" is a verb; using "read" might be considered verbatim. Safer to avoid "read". Use "retrieve", "consume". For "unget", use "push back". For "close", maybe "terminate". For "parts", maybe "segments". For "tell", maybe "position". For "iter", maybe "iterate". So avoid those exact method names.

Thus keywords list should not contain method names verbatim. So avoid "read", "unget", "close", "parts", "tell", "iter". Use synonyms.

Keywords: lazy, stream, iterator, bytes, backtrack, buffer, look-back, incremental parsing, protocol handling, data consumption, push-back.

Make sure each keyword is a single word? Not required but list of strings.

Let's craft JSON.

{
  "summary": "Provides a lazy byte stream wrapper that consumes data from an underlying iterator on demand, supports standard stream operations such as iteration and position tracking, and allows previously consumed bytes to be pushed back for later re-reading.",
  "business
